name: Shopska Salata
description: A traditional Bulgarian salad made from tomatoes, cucumbers, onions, and topped with a generous amount of sirene cheese.
steps: Chop tomatoes, cucumbers, and onions into bite-sized pieces.
Combine in a bowl and season with salt and olive oil.
Top with grated sirene cheese and a sprinkle of parsley before serving.
tips: Chill the vegetables before preparing for a refreshing starter.
Serve alongside a loaf of crusty bread.
Add roasted red peppers for additional flavor and color.

name: Kavarma
description: A hearty Bulgarian stew made with meat (typically pork or chicken), onions, mushrooms, and peppers, seasoned with paprika and herbs.
steps: Brown the meat in a pot with some oil.
Add chopped onions, peppers, and mushrooms to the pot and sauté until soft.
Stir in paprika, a splash of white wine, and tomato paste. Cover and simmer for an hour.
Season with salt, pepper, and fresh herbs before serving.
ingredients: 500g pork or chicken, cut into pieces
tips: Serve with a side of Bulgarian bread or over cooked rice.
Adjust the amount of paprika to taste for a spicier version.
Can be made ahead and reheated, as it tastes even better the next day.

name: Banitsa
description: A traditional Bulgarian pastry made from layers of phyllo dough filled with eggs and cheese.
steps: Mix beaten eggs with crumbled sirene cheese and yogurt.
Layer sheets of phyllo dough in a greased baking dish, brushing each with melted butter.
Spread the egg and cheese mixture between layers of phyllo.
Bake at 375°F until golden brown and puffed.
Cut into squares and serve hot.
tips: Keep phyllo dough covered with a damp towel to prevent drying out.
Serve with plain yogurt or a hot drink for a traditional breakfast.
Add spinach or leeks to the filling for a variation.

name: Mekitsa
description: A traditional Bulgarian breakfast, mekitsa is a deep-fried dough pastry, served with powdered sugar, honey, or jam.
steps: Mix flour, yeast, and yogurt to form a soft dough. Let it rise until doubled.
Heat oil in a deep fryer.
Roll out small pieces of dough and fry until golden brown on both sides.
Drain on paper towels and sprinkle with powdered sugar, or serve with honey or jam.
tips: Do not overcrowd the fryer to maintain a consistent temperature.
Serve immediately while hot for the best texture.
Experiment with savory versions by adding cheese or garlic to the dough.

name: Musaka
description: Bulgarian style moussaka is a baked dish of potatoes, minced meat, and a topping of yogurt and eggs, similar to the Greek version but without eggplant.
steps: Layer thinly sliced potatoes and seasoned minced meat in a baking dish.
Mix eggs with yogurt and pour over the layers.
Bake at 350°F until the top is golden and the potatoes are tender.
Allow to set before serving.
tips: Let the musaka sit for 10-15 minutes after baking to firm up for easier serving.
Add a layer of sautéed onions and carrots for extra flavor and moisture.
Serve with a side salad of cucumbers and tomatoes.

name: Tarator
description: A cold yogurt soup popular in the summer, made with cucumbers, garlic, dill, and walnuts.
steps: Combine yogurt with water to a soup-like consistency.
Add finely chopped cucumbers, crushed garlic, chopped dill, and crushed walnuts.
Season with salt and olive oil.
Chill in the fridge for at least an hour before serving.
tips: Serve very cold for a refreshing summer dish.
Add ice cubes just before serving to keep it chilled.
Experiment with adding other herbs like mint for a different flavor profile.

name: Kadaif
description: A dessert of shredded phyllo dough, baked with nuts and saturated with syrup.
steps: Layer kadaif dough in a tray, interspersing with mixed nuts.
Bake until golden brown.
Pour a hot syrup made of sugar, water, and lemon juice over the baked kadaif.
Let it cool and absorb the syrup before serving.
tips: Ensure the syrup is hot when poured over to soak the kadaif thoroughly.
Allow the kadaif to sit for several hours to fully absorb the syrup and enhance the flavors.
Serve with a dollop of whipped cream or a scoop of ice cream.

name: Bulgarian Cheese Toast
description: A quick and satisfying breakfast item made with bread, Bulgarian cheese, and often topped with a fried egg.
steps: Toast bread slices lightly.
Spread a thick layer of grated Bulgarian cheese on each slice.
Broil in the oven until the cheese is bubbly and golden.
Optionally top with a fried egg and serve immediately.
ingredients: 200g Bulgarian cheese (or feta cheese as substitute)
tips: Serve with a side of tomato slices or olives.
For extra flavor, add a sprinkle of paprika or black pepper on the cheese before broiling.
Ensure the bread is toasted first to prevent it from becoming soggy.

name: Garash Cake
description: A rich chocolate cake made with layers of walnut sponge cake and dark chocolate ganache, named after the Hungarian pastry chef Garash.
steps: Prepare walnut sponge layers by beating egg whites with sugar and folding in ground walnuts and flour.
Bake each layer separately until set.
Prepare chocolate ganache with heavy cream and dark chocolate.
Assemble the cake by layering sponge and ganache, finishing with a ganache topping.
Chill in the fridge to set before serving.
tips: Make sure each sponge layer is cooled before applying ganache.
If the ganache is too runny, chill it before spreading on the cake layers.
Decorate with walnut pieces or chocolate shavings for an elegant finish.

name: Sarmi
description: Traditional Bulgarian stuffed cabbage rolls filled with a mix of minced meats, rice, and herbs, cooked in a tomato-based sauce.
steps: Prepare cabbage leaves by boiling until tender.
Mix minced meat with rice, onions, and spices.
Place a spoonful of the filling on each leaf and roll tightly.
Arrange the rolls in a pot, cover with tomato sauce and water.
Simmer on low heat until the meat and rice are fully cooked.
Serve hot, garnished with fresh herbs.
tips: Ensure the cabbage leaves are not ripped to prevent filling from leaking out.
Add a bit of smoked meat to the pot for a deeper flavor.
Serve with a dollop of yogurt or sour cream.
